summary: This is an FBI 302 interview report of Dr. [REDACTED], the Chief Psychologist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), conducted on August 29, 2019. Dr. [REDACTED] details the psychological intake process, suicide watch protocols, and her extensive interactions with Jeffrey Epstein from his intake on July 8, 2019, until his death. She describes his psychological assessments, the July 23 incident with a noose, her hypotheses about it, housing decisions, and her conclusion that lack of a cellmate and understaffing contributed to his death.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.context: The interviewee, she oversaw psychological services for inmates including Jeffrey Epstein, conducted multiple suicide risk assessments on him, and was involved in decisions about his housing and observation status.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The high-profile inmate at MCC facing sex offense charges. The document details his psychological intake, assessments, the July 23 noose incident, his interactions with Dr. [REDACTED], his complaints, and his eventual death.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Epstein's cellmate in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Epstein claimed Tartaglione tried to kill him and called him a pedophile, leading to one of Dr. [REDACTED]'s hypotheses about the July 23 incident.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.context: A psychologist consulted by Dr. [REDACTED] regarding Epstein's risk factors upon intake. Also mentioned as attending a closeout meeting about Epstein's housing.

persons.name: Lt. [REDACTED]
persons.context: A SHU Lieutenant to whom Dr. [REDACTED] passed on Epstein's demands. Described as very regimented and regularly compliant with her requests.

persons.name: Dr. [REDACTED]
persons.context: A coordinator from the BOP Central Office who got involved in Epstein's housing and recommended he be housed with a sex offender in SHU.

connections.description: Dr. [REDACTED] was the chief psychologist responsible for Epstein's psychological assessments, suicide watch status, and acted as a conduit for his complaints to MCC executive staff.
Were cellmates in the SHU. Epstein accused Tartaglione of attempting to kill him and calling him a pedophile.
Dr. [REDACTED] consulted with Dr. [REDACTED] about Epstein's risk factors upon intake and later about his housing.
Dr. [REDACTED] passed Epstein's demands and concerns to Lt. [REDACTED] and described him as regimented and compliant.

events.title: Epstein's Psychological Intake
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein completed the Psychological Services Intake Questionnaire (PSIQ) at MCC. He marked nothing, which would typically result in a Care Code 1, but due to his high-profile status and charges, Dr. [REDACTED] ordered he be placed on observation.

events.title: Noose Incident and Suicide Watch
events.description: Epstein was found in his cell with a loose noose around his neck. He was placed on Suicide Watch and claimed he did not remember what happened, suggesting his cellmate Tartaglione tried to kill him. Dr. [REDACTED] completed a suicide risk assessment and developed three hypotheses: gaming, a rehearsal for suicide, or an assault.

events.title: Epstein Removed from Suicide Watch
events.description: Dr. [REDACTED] took Epstein off Suicide Watch and placed him on Psychological Observation after he reported being fearful of returning to his cell with Tartaglione, who had called him a pedophile.

events.title: Epstein Returned to SHU
events.description: Dr. [REDACTED] transitioned Epstein back to the Special Housing Unit (SHU) with the instruction he needed a cellmate for safety reasons (to decrease isolation, provide a rescue opportunity, etc.).

events.title: Epstein Signs New Will
events.description: Epstein signed a new will. Dr. [REDACTED] stated she was unaware of this; had she known, it would have been considered a red flag and he would have been placed back on Psychological Observation.

events.title: Epstein's Death
events.description: Implied by the document's context and Dr. [REDACTED]'s conclusion that the lack of a cellmate and understaffing contributed to his death.

locations: 1 Saint Andrews Plaza, New York, NY, 10007 (US Attorney's Office, Southern District of New York)
keyFacts: Dr. [REDACTED], MCC's Chief Psychologist, conducted three suicide risk assessments on Jeffrey Epstein, which she noted was unusual.

Following the July 23 noose incident, Dr. [REDACTED] had three hypotheses: 1) Gaming by Epstein/Tartaglione to manipulate the system, 2) A rehearsal by Epstein for suicide, or 3) An assault by Tartaglione.
Dr. [REDACTED] was unaware Epstein had signed a new will on August 8, 2019, which she stated would have been a major red flag prompting a return to Psychological Observation.
Dr. [REDACTED] emphasized the BOP policy that SHU inmates should have cellmates to decrease isolation and increase safety, and stated the lack of a cellmate for Epstein contributed to his death.

The document reveals that regular rounds by correctional officers in the SHU were not being completed, a fact inmates and officers would not report to executive staff like Dr. [REDACTED] due to fear of retaliation.
